awd_titl_txt: Raw Signal Processing and Peak Cluster Geometry to Discover and Quantify Co-Indicative Associations between Target and Non-Target Environmental Contaminants
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program in the Division of Chemistry, Profs. Ananya Sen Gupta and Keri Hornbuckle and their groups at the University of Iowa are devising data interpretation tools to facilitate discovery and quantitation of associations between well-known and unknown toxic pollutants. The key idea is to connect the "big picture" (what are the major causes and transport pathways of environmental contamination?) with small-scale details by mathematically resolving overlapped signals to discover hidden contributors to data from instruments used for separation and chemical analysis of contaminants. Studies of environmental pollution typically focus on known pollutants ("targets") and ignore the potentially significant roles played by unknown constituents. Non-target compounds can vastly outnumber known target compounds, and may be closely associated with, and strongly indicative of, the presence of target pollutants.  Experimental data often contains rich information about non-target compounds, but this information is rarely tracked in studies of environmental pollution or considered in regulatory policies. The Sen Gupta and Hornbuckle groups are addressing this gap by devising a novel suite of computational techniques to enhance recovery of information from complex experimental data. Their work is applicable to a wide range of chemical pollutants, such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and other industrial pollutants in city air; nitrates and arsenic in rural well-water; and hydrocarbon pollution from marine oil spills.  Beyond the scientific advances in pollution studies, the work is actively engaging women and other underrepresented groups through graduate and undergraduate research mentoring.

The Sen Gupta/Hornbuckle team is devising a suite of computational techniques to examine raw instrument signal (primarily from gas chromatography and mass spectrometry) and to autonomously detect contributions from both target and non-target compounds, enabling quantitation of their relative associations in environmental contamination. The approach combines non-linear optimization, geometric clustering, and graph-based multi-scale networks, where the target analytes form the local neighborhood hub and non-targets cluster around the target hubs forming dense association sub-graphs. Techniques are validated across multiple data repositories and multiple applications, seeking unprecedented comprehensive interpretation of raw chromatographic and mass spectrometric signals. Specific objectives include: (i) discovery of "hidden peaks" that co-elute with target compounds; (ii) identification of associations between target and non-target compounds to enhance identification of contamination pathways; and (iii) provision of tools enabling integration of diverse data repositories, potentially transforming understanding of environmental contamination pathways.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project outcomes

The main objective of this project was to understand the persistence, prevalence and provenance of chemical contaminants hazardous to public health that can infiltrate and perpetuate in the environment. The chemical contaminants considered spanned a wide variety of well-known compounds as well as potentially unknown compounds detected across different environmental pollution studies. The key idea was to isolate and interpret compound peaks, known or unknown, detected in the raw signal of analytical instrument used to process samples from different prior pollution studies. Accordingly, the intellectual merit and broader impact of the project are as follows.

Intellectual merit:

The primary intellectual merit of the project was to detect and establish the prevalence of key compounds that either exhibit persistence (slow weathering), or dominance across collected samples in a field experiment. Specific attention was given to whether a compound is well-known (target) or unknown (non-target) to environmental chemists in the context of the different pollution studies considered. The primary data science aim was to move beyond compound-agnostic multivariate statistical analysis (chemometrics) towards compound-cognizant autonomous identification and interpretation of the raw instrument signal. Data considered in this project included a diverse portfolio from several prior independently funded field experiments, with the overall goal of compound-cognizant interpretation in mind. 

Accordingly, we considered data from historic large-scale pollution events such as petroleum hydrocarbon contamination from the Deepwater Horizon oil spill (2010), and the Refugio pipeline oil leak (2015); as well as data from pollution studies that focus on the persistent yet invisible accumulation of toxic industrial contaminants such as polychlorobyphenyls (PCBs) in the environment. In the latter regard, we considered PCB studies in passive air samplers collected from different urban (Chicago) neighborhoods, provided by the Hornbuckle laboratory at the University of Iowa, as well as PCBs detected in milk samples across the US (provided by the United States Food and Drug Administration).

The common data science challenge in the diverse data considered was the difficulty of assessing which contaminants, target or non-target, really contribute towards the fingerprinting of a pollution source or detecting long-term persistence of industrial contamination. Accordingly, one of our main science-relevant findings was that the answer is dependent on the nature of the pollution source (e.g. most PCBs being well-known and specific industrial contaminants are already classified as target analytes, non-targets peaks were typically noise or unrelated contaminants in the raw signals considered) whereas many persistence hydrocarbons in crude oil included clusters of target and non-target compounds that co-occur with the target hydrocarbons. Another important computational finding of the project was that graph-based representation and visualization of compound peaks can be a powerful computational tool since: 

(i) graph representation is scalable, i.e. locally and globally interpretable, and therefore, enable automated compound-cognizant analysis of different compound groups in a parallel processed setting; 

(ii) persistence graphs, a computational product of this project, seek to autonomously detect, classify, and fingerprint persistent contamination and therefore, integrate compound-cognizant knowledge across multiple samples and field experiments.

(iii) graph-based representation can potentially facilitate graph-based learning and interpretation by AI-enabled cyberinfrastructure.  

Broader impact:

The most significant broader impact of this project has been in its educational objective of bringing diverse student talent into interdisciplinary research at the nexus of data science and environmental chemistry. Accordingly, many students, several of them female and under-represented STEM minorities, were funded by this project at different stages of their journey as undergraduate and graduate researchers. A Masters thesis was completed in the topic of PCB pollution of milk samples (provided by the FDA) by one female student who started on the project as an undergraduate researcher, grew curious and passionate about research to pursue a master's thesis, and now a doctoral student funded by a new project. This is a case study of how investing early in undergraduate talent can orient, recruit and retain the best students towards long-term academic research. Another female student pursued her senior honor's thesis on the topic of signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) challenges in isolating compound peaks from the raw instrument signal. The project also partially funded the initial stages of doctoral study by two other PhD students (one female), who explored the topics of air pollution and persistency of hydrocarbon pollution in oil spills, before choosing to pursue their doctoral study in other independently funded topics. Beyond educational and broader research accomplishments, this project achieved several interdisciplinary and multi-institutional collaborations across a broad set of environmental applications. Academic dissemination of the research results and other products were and continue to be achieved through journal and conference publications. The PI also organized and participated in several IEEE forums invested in marine pollution studies. In particular, they wrote the scholarly review of marine pollution due to oil spills in the high-visibility IEEE Planet Positive 2030 initiative publication Strong Sustainability by Design.
